events.title: Napier's Bones
events.description: John Napier invents Napier's Bones, a manual calculating device for multiplication and division.

events.title: Pascaline Calculator
events.description: Blaise Pascal develops the Pascaline, an early mechanical calculator capable of addition and subtraction.

events.title: Stepped Reckoner
events.description: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz creates the Stepped Reckoner, a mechanical calculator that performs all four arithmetic operations.

events.title: Difference Engine
events.description: Charles Babbage conceptualizes the Difference Engine, a mechanical device designed to compute polynomial functions.

events.title: Analytical Engine
events.description: Charles Babbage designs the Analytical Engine, considered the first general-purpose mechanical computer concept.

events.title: First Computer Program
events.description: Ada Lovelace writes the first algorithm intended for processing on the Analytical Engine, earning her the title of the first computer programmer.

events.title: Punch-Card Machine
events.description: Herman Hollerith invents the punch-card machine to assist in processing the U.S. Census data, leading to the formation of IBM.

events.title: Turing Machine
events.description: Alan Turing introduces the concept of the Turing Machine, laying the theoretical foundation for modern computing.

events.title: Z3 Computer
events.description: Konrad Zuse completes the Z3, the world's first programmable, fully automatic digital computer.

events.title: ENIAC Completed
events.description: The Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer (ENIAC) is completed, becoming the first general-purpose electronic digital computer.

events.title: Transistor Invented
events.description: John Bardeen, Walter Brattain, and William Shockley invent the transistor at Bell Labs, revolutionizing electronic circuits and leading to smaller, more efficient computers.

events.title: Ferranti Mark 1
events.description: The Ferranti Mark 1, the world's first commercially available general-purpose electronic computer, is delivered to the University of Manchester.

events.title: IBM 701
events.description: IBM introduces the 701, its first commercial scientific computer.

events.title: First Hard Disk Drive
events.description: IBM's 305 RAMAC is released, featuring the first hard disk drive for computer storage.

events.title: Dartmouth Conference
events.description: The term 'artificial intelligence' is coined at the Dartmouth Conference, marking the formal beginning of AI as a field of study.

events.title: Integrated Circuit
events.description: Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce independently invent the integrated circuit, paving the way for modern microelectronics.

events.title: MOSFET Transistor
events.description: The first working MOSFET (Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor Field-Effect Transistor) is built at Bell Labs, leading to the development of modern microprocessors.

events.title: IBM System/360
events.description: IBM announces the System/360, a family of mainframe computers that set standards for future computing.

events.title: Computer Mouse
events.description: Douglas Engelbart develops the first computer mouse at the Stanford Research Institute.

events.title: Moore's Law
events.description: Gordon Moore publishes Moore's Law, predicting the doubling of transistors on integrated circuits approximately every two years.

events.title: ELIZA Program
events.description: Joseph Weizenbaum develops ELIZA, one of the first natural language processing programs and chatbots, simulating conversation by pattern matching.

events.title: ARPANET Established
events.description: ARPANET, the precursor to the internet, is established, connecting four major universities in the U.S.

events.title: Intel 4004 Microprocessor
events.description: Intel introduces the 4004, the first commercially available microprocessor, containing 2,300 transistors.

events.title: C Programming Language
events.description: Dennis Ritchie develops the C programming language at Bell Labs, which becomes one of the most influential programming languages.

events.title: Xerox Alto
events.description: The Xerox Alto is developed, featuring the first computer with a graphical user interface (GUI) and mouse, influencing future personal computers.

events.title: Microsoft Founded
events.description: Microsoft is founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen, beginning the era of personal computer software.

events.title: Apple Computer Founded
events.description: Apple Computer Company is founded by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne.

events.title: Apple II Released
events.description: The Apple II is released, becoming one of the first highly successful mass-produced personal computers.

events.title: IBM PC Introduced
events.description: IBM introduces the IBM PC, setting a standard for personal computing hardware and establishing the PC-compatible market.

events.title: Domain Name System
events.description: The Domain Name System (DNS) is introduced, organizing the internet into a hierarchical structure with domain names.

events.title: Apple Macintosh
events.description: Apple launches the Macintosh, the first mass-market personal computer with a graphical user interface and mouse.

events.title: Windows 1.0
events.description: Microsoft releases Windows 1.0, its first graphical operating system, introducing a GUI to the MS-DOS environment.

events.title: World Wide Web Proposed
events.description: Tim Berners-Lee proposes the World Wide Web at CERN, revolutionizing information sharing and creating the foundation of the modern internet.

events.title: Linux Kernel Released
events.description: Linus Torvalds releases the first version of the Linux operating system kernel, creating an open-source alternative to Unix.

events.title: Mosaic Web Browser
events.description: The Mosaic web browser is released, popularizing the World Wide Web and making web browsing accessible to the general public.

events.title: Netscape Navigator
events.description: Netscape Navigator is released, becoming a dominant web browser and helping to commercialize the internet.

events.title: Java Programming Language
events.description: Sun Microsystems releases Java, a platform-independent programming language that becomes widely used for web applications.

events.title: Windows 95
events.description: Microsoft releases Windows 95, introducing the Start menu, taskbar, and improved multitasking capabilities.

events.title: Deep Blue Defeats Kasparov
events.description: IBM's Deep Blue becomes the first computer system to defeat a reigning world chess champion, Garry Kasparov, in a match under standard tournament conditions.

events.title: Google Founded
events.description: Google is founded by Larry Page and Sergey Brin, transforming web search with their PageRank algorithm.

events.title: Apple iPod
events.description: Apple introduces the iPod, revolutionizing portable music and digital media consumption.

events.title: Facebook Launched
events.description: Facebook is launched by Mark Zuckerberg, becoming a major social networking platform and changing how people connect online.

events.title: YouTube Founded
events.description: YouTube is founded by Chad Hurley, Steve Chen, and Jawed Karim, transforming video sharing on the internet.

events.title: Apple iPhone
events.description: Apple releases the iPhone, integrating computing, telephony, and internet access in a revolutionary mobile device.

events.title: Android OS Released
events.description: Google releases the first version of the Android operating system, creating an open-source mobile platform.

events.title: Apple iPad
events.description: Apple introduces the iPad, popularizing tablet computing and creating a new category of mobile devices.

events.title: IBM Watson Wins Jeopardy!
events.description: IBM's Watson computer system wins Jeopardy!, showcasing significant advancements in artificial intelligence and natural language processing.

events.title: Raspberry Pi Released
events.description: The Raspberry Pi, a low-cost, credit-card-sized computer, is released to promote computer science education and affordable computing.

events.title: Deep Learning Revolution
events.description: Deep neural networks achieve breakthrough results in image recognition at ImageNet competition, sparking the modern deep learning revolution.

events.title: Amazon Echo
events.description: Amazon introduces the Echo smart speaker with Alexa voice assistant, popularizing voice-controlled computing in homes.

events.title: Windows 10
events.description: Microsoft releases Windows 10, unifying its operating system across multiple device types including desktops, tablets, and phones.

events.title: AlphaGo Defeats Go Champion
events.description: AlphaGo, developed by Google's DeepMind, defeats world champion Lee Sedol in the board game Go, a major milestone in artificial intelligence.

events.title: Transformer Architecture
events.description: Google researchers introduce the Transformer architecture in 'Attention Is All You Need', revolutionizing natural language processing and enabling modern LLMs.

events.title: Quantum Supremacy
events.description: Google claims quantum supremacy with its 53-qubit Sycamore processor, performing a calculation that would take classical computers thousands of years.

events.title: GPT-3 Released
events.description: OpenAI releases GPT-3, a language model with 175 billion parameters capable of generating human-like text, marking a significant advancement in natural language processing.

events.title: Exascale Computing
events.description: Frontier becomes the world's fastest supercomputer, achieving exascale performance and ushering in a new era of high-performance computing.

events.title: ChatGPT Launched
events.description: OpenAI launches ChatGPT, an AI chatbot that gains over 100 million users within two months, becoming the fastest-growing consumer application in history.

events.title: GPT-4 Released
events.description: OpenAI releases GPT-4, a multimodal large language model capable of processing both text and images, with significant improvements in reasoning and instruction-following.
